Not a particularly hidden secret, mind youâ€”itâ€™s actually pretty hard to miss. The villageâ€™s claim to fame is the abnormal amount of twins [ http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/5306898/Indian-village-with-250-sets-of-twins.html ] born there. Kodinhi only has around 2,000 families, yet there are 250 sets of twins officially registered there. In fact, there could be many moreâ€”experts estimate there could be as many as 350 sets of twins in the area.It gets stranger. It is estimated that the number of twins born in the village is increasing every year, and no one really knows why [ http://news.sky.com/story/692499/india-twin-births-baffle-doctors-in-kerala ]. Doctors have absolutely no idea what is causing this strange phenomenon. They assume there must be some unknown hereditary factor at work, or maybe itâ€™s something they eat. However, it was more aggressive in nature, sounding a lot like a massive explosion. The citizens were concerned about the sound and asked around about it, but it soon turned out that no planes had been flying over the area and no explosions had taken place. The source of the â€œJodhpur boomâ€ was a complete mystery.The weirdest part is that it appears that the entire month was littered with strange, unexplained booms all over the world [ http://www.ufo-blogger.com/2012/12/sonic-boom-heard-in-usa-uk-and-india.html ], from United Kingdom to Texas. According to legend, this powerful secret society [ http://www.indohistory.com/nine_unknown_men.html ] was founded by Emperor Asoka in 273 BC after a bloody battle that took the lives of 100,000 men. Some of them are even said to hold the secrets of anti-gravity and time travel. Occasionally, some of this precious information leaks out into the worldâ€”for instance, it is said that the martial art of Judo was based on â€œleaksâ€ from the Book of Physiology.The number of the Unknown Men is always nine, and their undisguised contacts with the outside world are few and far between. Considered one of the modern wonders of the world, this ornate white marble building was created by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan as a mausoleum to his deceased wife. Or was it?According to some theories, Taj Mahal was never the architectural embodiment of eternal love [ http://www.hindunet.org/hindu_history/modern/godbole_taj1.html ] history remembers it as. Instead, some evidence suggests that the building is actually about 300 years older [ http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lbrvB3lltw ] than its supposed builder. New Delhi professor P.N. Oak, the man behind this theory, claims that the building was originally not a mausoleum at all. He suggests it is actually an ancient Hindu temple known as Tejo Mahalaya dedicated to the worship of the god Shiva. Is Taj Mahal as the ultimate display of romance just a giant lie created by shoddy historians and propagandists? Until the Indian government agrees to open the sealed rooms within the building so they can be thoroughly investigated by experts, the mystery remains.6 The Cursed Village Of KuldharaFor over 500 years, the village of Kuldhara was populated by about 1,500 residents. They didnâ€™t die or get abducted or anythingâ€”they just left. The reason for their sudden evacuation is lost in time. If you park your car on the road that leads to the top of the hill and leave it in neutral, it will roll up the steep road by its own accord, moving at speeds up to 20 kilometers per hour (12.4 mph). This wonderful naturalâ€”or, as some travel guides will tell you, supernaturalâ€”phenomenon is called a â€œHimalayan wonderâ€ and is a popular attraction for the travelers of the area.The real truth behind the â€œMagneticâ€ Hill of Ladakh is pretty impressive, but sadly, not quite as mysterious. These are (a) inertial confinement fusion (ICF) and (b) magnetic confinement fusion (MCF). Beside these we can define the group of miscellaneous concepts which contains electrostatic confinement, and hybrid concepts of MCF and ICF.Besides the distinction in technologies to create fusion there is a coarse distinction in the type of fusion, namely, neutronic and aneutronic fusion. Neutronic fusion means that primarily excess neutrons carry the energy of the fusion reaction and aneutronic fusion means that primarily excess charged particles carry the energy.Inertial confinementA problem with both the Z-machine and the NIF is not being able to have repeated shots, due to the huge power requirements per shot (for both) and the physical limitations of the liners (Z-machine) and the current lasers (NIF). During the coming years NIF is doing a proof-of-concept for nuclear fusion by laser-assisted inertial confinement. Depending on the developments at NIF, HIPER will be constructed in 2028.It provides a different angle for plasma research than controlled fusion which could be used in for instance plasma accelerator development, high energy laser development and tracking technologies.Magnetic confinementThe Tokamak design has been built since the 1950's in various forms and since then the performance numbers have exponentially increased in time with increased size of the reactors and with evolving operating regimes.With project ITER the reactor size is again increased and the expected increase in performance should lead to a net gain in energy over longer confinement times (in the order of minutes). This should take place between 2025-2030. If successful, a follow-up reactor will be built to demonstrate final application as a power plant, between 2045-2055.This is the most costly project so far, but also the one in which the most experience has been built up, systematically and rigourously. The major uncertainty is the quality of the superconducting coils which will only have a cold-test before they are integrated in the final assembly. The established design being worked on today assumes a so-called high-confinement mode (H-mode) as the operating regime. This mode was accidentally discovered in the early eighties during experiments at ASDEX in Germany. However it is accompanied by instabilities at the edge of the plasma (ELM's) which for ITER-sized reactors would lead to destructive heat fluxes going towards the walls, unless the instabilities are continuously mitigated or controlled.In the Tokamak reactor the helical field lines which hold the plasma together are formed by an induced current and toroidal field coils. This current drive is also the cause of many instabilities. In theCategory C, the smaller experimentsAn example of an IEC is the polywell by EMC2. The latest design by EMC2 (the WB8) is still being tested, if successful a 100 MW-design will follow and an aneutronic version o f the WB8 design. A major issue with polywells is their inefficiency to produce fusion reactions due to electron leakage.As an example of FRC, a company called Tri-alpha is developing a magnetic-mirror concept to facilitate aneutronic fusion, it has gathered over $100 million from private investors. The magnetic mirror machine is potentially much simpler and much smaller than the Tokamak-designs. An important advantage is the  fact the fusion products are charged and can thus be used directly to generate electric energy, and since it is charged it can be manipulated using magnetic fields. The charged fusion products can for instance be focussed to create a compact direct power conversion. Important downside is leakage of particles due to the open field line through the center, reducing the efficiency.Focus fusion plasma holds some promise to produce efficient fusion power, however it's reliance on instabilities to generate enough plasma energy/density make it difficult to develop into a continuous and stable energy source, also it is unclear how and if this design can be scaled up to produce net energy.Hybrid concepts: for instance the one by General Fusion, which entails the use of hundreds of cylinders impinging on a single point (equally timed within microseconds) to compress rotating liquid lithium and liquid Lead through shockwaves onto a magnetically confined D-T plasma vortex which is shot into the cavity of the sphere. Here the lithium acts as the Tritium source and energy is transferred through the liquid heating up and expanding. Difficulties are mostly of engineering nature, the problems experienced by magnetic confinement fusion are of less importance here because the confinement time is kept very small. This is called Magnetized Target Fusion (MTF), here a plasmoid of low density is compressed to obtain the require confinement time for fusion.The hybrid concept MagLIF is a combination of a Z-pinch machine and a laser based confinement system. The basic mode of operation is as follows, first a magnetically confined plasma of deuterium and tritium is generated in a Hohlraum using a high-power laser, then the Hohlraum is pinched (i.e. compressed) by a current shot. Again, just as with the Z-machine, and the NIF, repeated shots are very difficult due to excessive heat loads on the liners, which carry the huge currentshots in the order of 50 million amperes.Another concept is a hybrid fusion/fission reactor, where part of the output energy is delivered by a fission reaction which is catalyzed by the high energy neutrons from the fusion reactions. This way fissionable material can be used without producing much (if any) nuclear waste.The major difficulties for sustained energy production, for both inertial and magnetic confinement are; (I) material degradation and activation due to neutron fluency [especially for neutronic fusion], (II) pollution control, (III) maintenance and specifically for magnetic confinement; continuous control of the plasma dynamics and prevention of damaging instabilities (IV).(I) Neutron fluency destabilizes wall materials to produce short-lived radioactive waste, and due to transmutation actually change the element type, Wolfram for instance can change to Lead. A possible solution that is being experimented with now is the use of liquid lithium flowing over the reactor walls.(II) How do we insert fuel without creating too much disturbance and how do we get rid of the fusion products efficiently.(III) As said, especially for neutronic fusion the wall will be radioactive and maintenance of the components inside the reactor will require special robotic tools.(IV) Confinement time is one of the most important performance indicators of any experimental magnetic confinement fusion reactor. It requires control systems which can (predictively) respond accurately within milliseconds and continuous monitoring of all the relevant plasma parameters. The relatively low density of the plasma requires relatively long confinement times for there to be enough collisions. This requirement of long confinement time is the most limiting factor for MCF, regardless of whether the reaction is neutronic or aneutronic.Aneutronic fusion requires much higher temperatures and it is likely less stable in terms of plasma dynamics due to the heavier Boron ions. However, a pure aneutronic fusion reaction will not (radio)activate and degrade the wall, it will open up the possibility for direct power conversion as well as magnetic control over the expelled fusion products since they are charged.Superconducting coilsI mention this separately because technological developments in this area are not only crucial for the viability of magnetic confinement fusion, they are also partly detached from the fusion plasma research in the sense that maximizing the maximum magnetic field that can be generated is a goal in itself.There are two recent developments of interest for this topic:I personally have no doubt that we will harness fusion energy. In terms of technology it is not a matter of possible or impossible but rather of perseverance, boldness and expediency. Expediency, because nuclear fusion is likely to require more time to reach full potential then for instance solar or wind energy which are already being put to market. So there is a risk of the public and politics losing interest and thus of funding being cut away from the big projects like ITER and HIPER. In the mean time a lot of private investment capital is being spent on experimental, say category (c), concepts which hold promise of success but certainly do not give guarantees. This requires boldness now, and especially in the future if these concepts do not immediately live up to expectations. Perseverance because the concept of nuclear fusion is by far superior to wind or solar in terms of the technology gained and the ecological footprint it leaves.Please add/edit.
